title: Re: Bio Menace challenge
content:
IIRC...

BMENACE1.EXE TEDLEVEL 24

Not sure if 24 is the correct level number for the high scores screen. I did this some time ago with the Apogee splash "level" and the Secret level entrance "level" too.

This works with the 3 episodes.------------------------------

title: Re: Bio Menace challenge
content:
In DOSBox 0.65 and earlier, you must use a patch provided in DOSBox's website (search in the game database).

DOSBox 0.70 runs Bio Menace correctly without any patches, so you'd better upgrade. It also runs DN3D without performace issues. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-helmet.gif[/img]

3D Realms provided the patch for DOSBox 0.63 with the freeware release of Bio Menace. I had to download the one for DOSBox 0.65 later.

Now that I use DOSBox 0.70, I need no patch. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] ------------------------------

title: Re: Bio Menace challenge
content:
Patch? Level edited with TED5 so that the player sprite is on that building?

TEDLEVEL doesn't work properly for the high scores screen in Keen 4 because the EXE tries to find the "level entrance text" for that level, which isn't present except in Keen 5 ("Keen finds himself...") and Keen 6 ("Call ID!"). So, it probably causes a memory access violation instantly.

Bio Menace doesn't use level entrance text, it just uses the map name from the GAMEMAPS file.

CK 4-6 , btw, read the level name (the one displayed in the status window) from the EXE, not from the GAMEMAPS.------------------------------

title: Re: Bio Menace challenge
content:
For those who don't also browse the 3DRealms forums, I've now published the [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/Bio_Menace_Cheat_Codes]new Bio Menace cheat codes[/url].

I think it's interesting that the Bio Menace jump cheat works the same way as the Keen Dreams one (in that you can't jump again if you're in the process of falling.) Aside from being quite annoying, it makes me wonder whether Bio Menace originated from the Keen Dreams engine (or a very early Keen 4 engine.) I always assumed it came at least after Keen 4.[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

title: Re: Bio Menace challenge
content:
I used a disassembler to pull apart the code, and then slowly figured out what it was doing. It took a couple of literally full days (only stopping to eat and sleep) but I really enjoyed it. I've never done anything like that before, so now I know how to do it, it should be much easier next time.

The JIM+Space key combination is a bit weird, it's set up so that if you push the spacebar first, it won't check for the other keys. You have to hold down J+I+M first, and then press the spacebar last.[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

title: Re: Bio Menace challenge
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]
Malvineous wrote: I think it's interesting that the Bio Menace jump cheat works the same way as the Keen Dreams one (in that you can't jump again if you're in the process of falling.) Aside from being quite annoying, it makes me wonder whether Bio Menace originated from the Keen Dreams engine (or a very early Keen 4 engine.) I always assumed it came at least after Keen 4.
[hr][/quote]

My theory is that Id Software licensed the vanilla Keen: Galaxy engine for Apogee. By "vanilla", I mean a source code distribution that was later heavily modified to produce the released Keen Dreams, 4, 5 and 6 games. The main modifications might be the menu screen layout (changed only in Keen Dreams), the level-entering mode (Keen Dreams and Bio Menace display a progress bar when you load a level), the physics system (Bio Menace and Keen Dreams share a more standard, less Keenish system), the cheat activation mechanism (Keen Dreams and Keen 6 v1.0 don't require an activator, while later versions of Keen 4-6 and Bio Menace do), and the text screens (in Keen 4-5 you have a red background with the yellow line bitmaps read from EGAGRAPH, while in Keen 6 v1.0 you have a gray background, v1.4 has a plain red background, and Bio Menace uses blue background with the line bitmaps read from EGAGRAPH too). However, most of the physics system, sprite manager, tile manager and tile map/TED5 format I/O system, remain unmodified between the games in question.

That's what leads me to think Id licensed a vanilla source code distribution for Bio Menace. Also, it's possible, since Keen Dreams was developed later IIRC, and only for Softdisk, that they used the same distribution with minor modifications (for Softdisk likings) to produce the Keen Dreams engine, and they didn't have enough time to put the pogo in and such things.

(BTW, you can see this vanilla thing if you compare the differences and similarities between all WinXP/.NET editions; Home Edition, for instance, has a mangled networking subsystem.)------------------------------
[url=http://shadowm2006.sitesled.com/]My website[/url]

My guess is that the freeware release is a later version than the other v1.1 registered version. When you start the freeware version, you get a screen with some technical help for when you have problems with the game. I don't get this helpful screen in the other v1.1 version of Bio Menace. I guess the freeware release version is from a time after their "We hate cheats"-period, so they enabled the cheats again.Groeten van Frenkel
